comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: The Tyrrell Collection at the Powerhouse Museum appears to include copy negatives, albeit glass plate negatives, of some of the images of The Rocks originally taken by John Degotardi Junior as part of his employment by the Department of Public Works. The images cover the area of The Rocks that was gazetted for resumption in the NSW Government Gazette No.1203 on 29 December 1900, pp10123-4, under the the Darling Harbour Wharves Resumption Act 1900 (Act No.10, 1900). State Records holds, as part of NRS 4481, the original 8 inch x 10 inch glass plate negatives from which these direct contact prints were made in the 1970s. It is thought that the negatives in the Tyrrell Collection are copy negatives because the images appear two to a plate. See for example Tyrrell Collection 85/1286-775 www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=379072&... Also Tyrrell Collection 85/1286-776 shows light reflected in the bottom left corner of the top image, as though the print had been crumpled. www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=379074&... It would be interesting to find out if the captions appear on the negatives at the Powerhouse Museum in ink on the emulsion side as they do on the negatives in NRS 4481. JS

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Thanks JS @ SRNSW. That's very interesting information. 

The State Library of NSW also holds copy prints of Degotardi's plague work in what are called the plague books. I've seen them on display, and those certainly pre-date the 1970s. They look more likely contemporaneous to the plague era.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: This photo was recently determined to be part of the Rocks Resumption photographic survey, the title and date of the image has been changed accordingly Here is a map of the Rocks Resumption area (last one in the sequence)
